summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney to the U.S. Attorney's Office, providing a preliminary list of documents the defense may use in its case-in-chief at trial. The letter outlines the defense's disclosure obligations under Rule 16 and lists 12 categories of potential evidence, including phone records, flight manifests, police reports, and the Jeffrey Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, for whom the defense attorney is providing Rule 16 disclosures.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP who authored the letter to the U.S. Attorney's Office, providing the defense's Rule 16 disclosures on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to the 'Jeffrey Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement' listed as potential defense evidence.

persons.name: Larry Visoski
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to flight manifests that are listed as potential defense evidence.

persons.name: Judge Koeltl
persons.context: Mentioned as the judge presiding over the case Doe v. Indyke, from whom a release related to the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program is pending.

connections.description: Everdell is the defense attorney providing legal representation and disclosures for Maxwell in her criminal case.
Maxwell's defense is listing the Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement as potential evidence, indicating their cases are connected.
Visoski's flight manifests are listed as defense evidence, suggesting he was a pilot for Epstein/Maxwell's travel operations.

events.title: Court Order for Defense Disclosures
events.description: The court issued an order requiring the defense to provide disclosures under Rule 16 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure.

events.title: Defense Rule 16 Disclosure Submission
events.description: Maxwell's defense attorneys submitted preliminary list of documents they may use in their case-in-chief to the U.S. Attorney's Office.

events.title: Meeting Referenced in Defense Materials
events.description: Meeting materials from this date are listed as potential defense evidence (Item 12 in the disclosure list).

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team provided a preliminary list of 12 categories of documents they may use in their case-in-chief, including the Jeffrey Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement.
The defense explicitly states they are under no obligation to present a defense case and final decisions will depend on trial developments.

Key evidence categories include AT&T phone records, Federal Express records, Customs and Border Patrol records, flight manifests from pilot Larry Visoski, and Palm Beach Police Department incident reports.
The defense references documents from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, including a general release pending from Judge Koeltl in a related civil case.

The letter establishes the defense's position on disclosure obligations, arguing Rule 16 doesn't require disclosure of impeachment evidence or documents used to refresh witness recollection during the government's case.
